data.title: The Year in Review—Anything but Dull - Orthoworld
data.meta_description: The Year in Review—Anything but Dull - Orthoworld
data.text: The Year in Review – Anything but Dull This past year brought with it plenty of anticipated and unanticipated excitement in all areas of orthopaedics – a super large merger, the largest private equity transaction in history, a government investigation that brought more than $300 million to Medicare’s coffers and keeps going for more, new and young CEOs at four of the largest orthopaedic companies, more porous metals and gender-based initiatives, cervical discs, hefty patent infringement payouts…Here’s a brief review of happenings in 2007. Biomet Goes Private and Smith & Nephew Rises to #4 Position in Joint Replacement Two of the largest deals in orthopaedic history occurred in 2007 – a private equity consortium’s purchase of Biomet for more than $11 billion and Medtronic’s acquisition of Kyphon for more than $4 billion. The Biomet purchase changed some key faces inside the company and set a new course for the company, particularly within its EBI division. The Medtronic (MDT) purchase of Kyphon solidly positions MDT in the realm of vertebral compression fracture (VCF) repair and treatment for spinal stenosis, the latter thanks to Kyphon’s acquisition of St. Francis early in the year. At year’s end, Kyphon completed its purchase of the non-vertebroplasty assets of Disc-O-Tech Medical Technologies and entered into a definitive agreement to divest all assets relating to the Disc-O-Tech Confidence VCF product line. Those assets became part of the DePuy Spine franchise. In other M&A activities, Tornier expanded its small bone business with acquisitions of Nexa Orthopedics and DVO Extremity Solutions. Wright Medical also beefed up its small bone franchise with purchases of Darco International’s reconstructive foot surgery business, the BIO-ARCH subtalar implant from Metasurg and certain foot- and ankle-focused external fixation assets from R&R Medical. At the same time, Wright divested of its Adcon-L by selling the spinal adhesion barrier gel to aap. Aap completed its acquisition of all shares in FAME Holding and its subsidiaries and renamed itself aap BioImplants, bespeaking its new focus on biomaterials. Integra’s purchase of IsoTis also centered on biologics and will help the company build its burgeoning orthobiologics/spinal franchise with one of the largest biologics distribution networks in the U.S. Another biologics move came when Pioneer Surgical Technology acquired Angstrom Medica, whose products include nanocrystalline calcium phosphate with application in trauma, spine and general orthopaedics. ReAble continues to build a solid rehabilitation franchise, this time adding DJO to its coffers in a $1.6 billion deal. A smaller rehab deal came with BSN’s purchase of FLA Orthopedics. The merger of INBONE Technologies and Reiley Orthopaedic combined a total ankle with a titanium intramedullary fusion system. Kensey’s acquisition of Cytori’s MacroPore Biosurgery spinal and orthopaedic business unit broadened its reach in resorbable technologies, while Exactech’s decision to acquire spine-focused Altiva took it into the realm of spine for the first time. Also in spine, Zimmer bought Endius and added solid computer-assisted sur- 50 Orthopaedic Product News • January/February 2008 FISCAL FITNESS Author: Shirley A. Engelhardt gery expertise with its purchase of ORTHOsoft. Finally, Smith & Nephew’s $889 million acquisition of Plus expanded its presence in Europe and helped the company displace Biomet as the 4th largest joint replacement company in the world. Biologics and Spine Deals Dominate the Landscape Since many companies had neither the funds nor the inclination to spend millions or billions of dollars on a Plus or a Kyphon, a variety of strategic partnerships arose in product development, distribution, collaborations, etc. For example, with its 2006 move away from Medtronic and Exactech as its exclusive partners for distribution of certain of its tissuebased products, Regeneration Technologies (RTI) was able to ink deals with Wright Medical (xenograft implants for foot and ankle surgeries), Stryker (Bio-Cleanse-sterilized spinal allografts) and Zimmer (next generation allograft paste). RTI also made a deal with CryoLife for the latter to cease distributing orthopaedic tissues and at year’s end, entered into a definitive agreement with Tutogen to merge. Other orthobiologics deals ranged from Bonesupport’s agreement with Signus for distribution of Cerament bone void filler in certain states to Kensey Nash’s development of bone void fillers for Biomet, MIV Therapeutics’ collaboration with Smith & Nephew for new hydroxyapatite-based coatings and drug delivery systems and Spinal Restoration and Baxter evaluating Tisseel fibrin sealant as part of the Biostat Disc Augmentation System. Among deals in the orthopaedic space, those related to spine dominated the scene in 2007, as has been the case for a number of years. Alliances formed between Altiva and NAS Medical; Medtronic and Takiron; NuVasive and Theken; Smith & Nephew and Teknimed; SpineSource and A-Spine, Anatomica and Creaspine; and X-Spine and Highland Medical. The most action in alliances and in spine, however, came through Alphatec. During 2007, the company signed license agreements with Scient’x, Roger Jackson, M.D., Stout Medical, JGMG Bengochea and Progressive Spinal Technologies for a variety of products from dynamic stabilization systems to an expandable titanium cage. Spine aside, alliances were reached for computer assisted surgical technologies (Acrobot/Stanmore, Zimmer/ORTHOsoft), diagnostics (Axial Biotech/DePuy), imaging (Medtronic/Breakaway Imaging), joint replacement (Biomet/Massachusetts General Hospital, Corin/Stryker), neuromonitoring (MDT/Axon), orthopaedic support devices (Enova Medical/Product Innovations, minSurg/Bauerfeind), pain management (Synergetics/Stryker) and small bone products (Bioretec/Nexa, Integra/InteliFUSE, Small Bone Innovations/Euromedic, Implants International and LITOS, Wright Medical/aap and A.M. Surgical). On the sale side of things, Xylos divested of its wound care business to accelerate product development with particular focus on musculoskeletal repair.
